Award.AwardTitle: Bottom-Up Manufacturing of Sustainable Magnetic Nanocrystal Assembly

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Monodispersed (uniform size) magnetic nanocrystals have been successfully applied in high energy density magnet, data storage and biotechnology applications. However, it has remained a challenge to achieve the ordered structure needed in a large scale due to different types of planar defects in the nanocrystals. The objective of this project is to produce and study metastable, epitaxially stabilized rare-earth-free magnetic ferrous nanocrystals using bottom-up core/shell interdiffusion process with nanoscale precision. High energy density magnetic nanocomposites will be developed through the self-assembled exchange-coupling (magnetic interaction) of magnetically hard and soft nanocrystals, which will be scaled up by high-throughput microwave processing. The ultimate goal is to demonstrate a bottom-up manufacturing strategy to discover rare-earth-free high-energy density magnetic nanomaterials.

This study will represent a versatile nanomanufacturing route for magnetic alloy nanocrystals with unprecedented control of their structures, and create a rational pathway for manipulating bottom-up assembly-controlled exchange-coupling processes. In addition, discovering rare-earth-free high energy density nanomagnets from low cost elements, such as iron and nickel, represent a critical part of present and future sustainable high energy density applications, including smaller, lighter and more efficient motors and generators, as well as non-invasive magnetic hyperthermia biotechnology. A successfully developed ferrous based spring nanomagnets will (1) reduce the U.S. dependence on rare-earth imports; (2) reduce cost and improve efficiency of high energy density applications; and (3) establish U.S. leadership in a wide adoption of green energy technologies. In addition, the benefit to society is that successful results will lead to advances in earth abundant materials and environmentally benign manufacturing applications.

Institution.Name: Temple University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Summary

NSF 1553986: Bottom-Up Manufacturing of Sustainable Magnetic Nanocrystal Assembly 

Shenqiang Ren, Temple University

 

The ultimate objectives of this project include both research and education components, 1) initiating a new bottom-up nanomanufacturing strategy to controllably and scalable grow magnetic functional nanomaterials, which represents a versatile nanomanufacturing route for magnetic alloy nanocrystals with unprecedented control of their structures, and create a rational pathway for manipulating bottom-up assembly processes; and 2) the benefit to society is that successful results lead to advances in earth abundant materials and environmentally benign manufacturing applications.

 

Covering the entire life of the award, we have been developing a scalable nanomanufacturing strategy to create nanoalloys without the use of harsh reducing agents and stabilizing ligands, so that contaminate free metal nanoalloys can be generated. It is the goal that this strategy will be versatile in its ability to create many different types of metal alloys, bi and tri-metallic. Also, control of final stoichiometry within the alloys will be necessary to achieve to make this a competitive methodology. The generation of unique nanoalloys never before generated via solution processing strategies have been targeted to prove this methodologies usefulness. Remarkable interest in nanocrystalline metals and alloys has been generated recently due to their intriguing properties such as high surface area to volume ratio, extreme strength and unique nano-sized properties. Many types of metal alloys nanoparticles have been created and studied for catalytic and magnetic applications. Solution processing strategies for generation of these metal nanoalloys is widely used as a standard method due to its versatility and the ease of scale up it provides.

 

Being a bottom up strategy, the standard synthesis requires three main components: metal precursors (usually metal salts), reducing agents and organic ligands. The metals being used dictate the required reducing agent that is used to reduce the ion back to a zero-valent state. Many times, harsh reducing agents are necessary, adding complexity and safety concerns of injecting highly reactive species into hot reaction solutions. Moreover, with bi or trimetallic alloys, the reduction rate differences between the two metal species can create issues in forming alloys. Stabilizing ligands are also utilized in many synthesis, providing growth and shape control of the nanoalloys. However, after synthesis, these ligands still are present on the final metal alloys coordinated to the active sites of the metals, reducing catalytic efficiency. Ligands do not only hurt catalytic properties, magnetic nanoalloys can also be affected by residual ligands. It has been seen that during high temperature annealing, these ligands turn into a carbonaceous matrix, adding non-magnetic mass to the alloys, reducing their magnetic performance. In extreme cases, the functional head group of the ligand (such as phosphine) can even dope into the magnetic phase, creating nonmagnetic phases and severely lowering their magnetic properties.

 

The success of this project leads to a breakthrough for the development of cost-effective high energy product magnetic nanocrystals with enhanced magnetic, and catalytic properties, as a new generation of earth abundant nanometals. Such a nanomanufacturing technology offers a golden opportunity for sustainable and environmental beneficial magnet systems. Methodologies and knowledge developed through the course of the project have been applicable to a broad range of earth abundant energy-critical metal nanomaterials. Green chemistry principles are significantly advanced through new methods to synthesize metal nanoalloys specifically designed for high energy product magnets and resource-efficient catalysts with high recycling efficiency. The metal-redox methodology, complementary modeling efforts and novel structure/property characterization tools stemming from this program significantly advance our fundamental understanding of structure-function relationships with broad applications in a variety of metal nanoalloys. In addition, this project has been actively engaging female and under-represented undergraduate researchers. These students have distinguished themselves in a number of ways: five of them are co-authors on peer-reviewed journal articles.

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2017
Modified by: Shenqiang Ren
